body:
Comment 1: 
I don't see what is inconsistent here.

Referring to a different interface in the definition of an interface just means copying
the methods.  If those methods are exported, then they are exported.  If they are not,
they are not.  Your example of a.(one.inner) is separate from the copying of the
interface methods. Since one.inner is not exported, that expression is invalid.

Embedding a struct in another struct means that the fields and methods of the first
struct become methods of the second struct.  If the methods are exported, then they are
exported.  That doesn't mean that you can refer to the first struct if it is not
exported.

I think this is all clearly described in the spec and I don't see the inconsistency.
